					<item>
		<title><![CDATA[How to Choose the Perfect Duration for Your Term Life Insurance]]></title>
		<link>https://dev.familyraksha.com/how-to-choose-the-perfect-duration-term-insurance/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 10 Aug 2024 09:56:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[digital]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.familyraksha.com/?p=180</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Term life insurance is a type of life insurance that provides coverage for a specific period of time, known as the "term." If the insured person passes away during the term, the insurance company pays out a death benefit to the designated beneficiaries. If the insured person survives the term, the policy typically expires without any payout.

Choosing the perfect duration for your term life insurance involves careful consideration of your financial goals, obligations, and circumstances. Here's a step-by-step guide to help you make an informed decision:
<h2>Assess Your Financial Goals and Needs:</h2>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Determine the purpose of the insurance</strong>: Are you seeking to provide financial protection for your family, cover specific debts (like a mortgage or student loans), or ensure your children's education?</li>
 	<li><strong>Consider your current financial obligations</strong>: Calculate your outstanding debts, ongoing expenses, and future financial needs. These may include mortgage payments, outstanding loans, education costs, and daily living expenses.</li>
 	<li><strong>Evaluate your dependents' needs</strong>: If you have dependents (spouse, children, elderly parents), consider how long they will need financial support in your absence.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Estimate the Time frame:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Decide how many years you need coverage</strong>: Consider how many years it will take to achieve your financial goals, pay off debts, or until your dependents become financially independent.</li>
 	<li><strong>Factor in major life events</strong>: Anticipate significant life changes such as your children's graduation, retirement, or paying off major debts.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Select the Term Length:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Short-term vs. long-term</strong>: Term life insurance typically comes in terms of 10, 15, 20, 25, or 30 years. Choose a term that aligns with your financial goals. For example, if you want coverage until your mortgage is paid off, a 20- or 30-year term might be appropriate.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Consider Your Budget:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Premium affordability</strong>: Longer terms usually come with higher premiums. Choose a term length that you can comfortably afford throughout the policy duration.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Evaluate Health and Age:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Health status</strong>: If you're younger and healthier, you may opt for a longer term to lock in lower premiums. If you're older or have health concerns, a shorter term might be more suitable.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Future Flexibility:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Convertibility</strong>: Some term policies offer the option to convert to permanent life insurance without a medical exam. This can be valuable if your circumstances change and you want lifelong coverage.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Consult a Financial Advisor or Insurance Agent:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li>An experienced professional can help you navigate the complexities of <a href="https://www.familyraksha.com/category/insurance/">life insurance</a> and provide personalized recommendations based on your unique situation.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Review and Update Regularly:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Life changes</strong>: Reevaluate your insurance needs periodically, especially after major life events like marriage, birth of a child, or a significant change in income.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Shop Around and Compare Quotes:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li>Obtain quotes from multiple insurance providers to find the best coverage and premiums for your chosen term length.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Read the Policy Carefully:</h3>
Understand the terms, conditions, and any exclusions associated with the <a href="https://www.familyraksha.com/term-insurance-plans-tips-for-finding-the-right-policy/">term insurance policy</a> before finalizing your decision.

There is no one-size-fits-all answer to choosing the perfect term length for your life insurance. It's a decision that requires thoughtful consideration of your unique circumstances and financial objectives.]]></content:encoded>

					<item>
		<title><![CDATA[5 Mistakes to Avoid When Buying Term Life Insurance]]></title>
		<link>https://dev.familyraksha.com/5-mistakes-to-avoid-when-buying-term-life-insurance/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 10 Aug 2024 09:56:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[digital]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.familyraksha.com/?p=187</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Buying term life insurance is an important decision that can provide financial security for your loved ones in case of your untimely passing. To make the right choices, it's important to avoid common mistakes. Here are five mistakes to avoid when buying term life insurance:
<h2>Not Adequately Assessing Your Needs</h2>
One of the biggest mistakes is not accurately evaluating how much coverage you need. Many people either overestimate or underestimate their coverage requirements. Consider factors like your outstanding debts, future expenses (like children's education), and your family's ongoing financial needs when determining the coverage amount.
<h2>Choosing the Wrong Term Length</h2>
Term life insurance comes in various term lengths, such as 10, 20, or 30 years. Selecting the wrong term length can leave you without coverage when you still need it or paying for unnecessary coverage. Assess your needs and choose a term that aligns with your financial goals and timeline.
<h2>Focusing Solely on Price</h2>
While cost is an important factor, solely focusing on finding the cheapest premium can lead to inadequate coverage or unreliable insurers. It's essential to consider the financial stability and reputation of the insurance company along with the policy's features and benefits.
<h2>Not Disclosing Relevant Information</h2>
Providing accurate and complete information about your health, lifestyle, and habits is crucial when applying for life insurance. Failing to disclose relevant information or providing false details can result in claims being denied later on. The insurance company will likely investigate your medical history, so honesty is key.
<h2>Not Comparing Multiple Quotes</h2>
Different insurance companies offer different rates and policy terms. Failing to compare quotes from multiple reputable insurers can lead to overpaying for coverage. Use online tools or work with an independent insurance agent to gather and compare quotes before making a decision.

<a href="https://www.familyraksha.com/term-insurance-plans-tips-for-finding-the-right-policy/">Term life insurance</a> is designed to provide financial protection for a specific period. It's not an investment or savings tool. Take your time to research, understand the policy terms, and make an informed decision based on your unique circumstances and goals. If needed, consider consulting with a financial advisor to ensure you're making the right choice for your family's future.]]></content:encoded>

							</item>
					<item>
		<title><![CDATA[Term Life Insurance Vs. Permanent Life Insurance: Which One Fits Your Needs?]]></title>
		<link>https://dev.familyraksha.com/term-life-insurance-vs-permanent-life-insurance/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 10 Aug 2024 09:56:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[digital]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.familyraksha.com/?p=190</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Term Life Insurance and Permanent Life Insurance are two main types of life insurance policies, each with its own features and benefits. The choice between them depends on your individual financial goals, circumstances, and preferences. Let's compare the two:
<h2>Term Life Insurance:</h2>
<strong>Coverage Duration</strong>: Term life insurance provides coverage for a specific period, such as 10, 20, or 30 years. If you pass away during the term, your beneficiaries receive the death benefit.

<strong>Affordability</strong>: Term insurance is generally more affordable than permanent insurance, especially for younger individuals. Premiums remain constant for the duration of the term but may increase when you renew the policy.

<strong>Simplicity</strong>: It's straightforward: you pay premiums for the term, and if you die during that time, your beneficiaries receive the death benefit. There's no cash value component.

<strong>No Cash Value</strong>: Term policies don't build cash value over time. Once the term ends, you typically won't receive any return on the premiums you've paid.

<strong>Ideal For</strong>: <a href="https://www.familyraksha.com/category/insurance/">Term life insurance</a> is often chosen by those who need coverage for a specific period, such as until their mortgage is paid off or until their children are financially independent.
<h2>Permanent Life Insurance:</h2>
<strong>Coverage Duration</strong>: Permanent life insurance provides coverage for your entire lifetime, as long as premiums are paid.

<strong>Cash Value</strong>: Permanent policies, such as whole life and universal life, have a cash value component. A portion of your premium goes into an investment account, which grows over time and can be accessed or borrowed against.

<strong>Premiums</strong>: Premiums for permanent insurance are significantly higher than those for term insurance. A portion of the premium goes towards the insurance coverage, and the rest helps build the cash value.

<strong>Investment Component</strong>: The cash value of permanent life insurance can be used for various purposes, including supplementing retirement income or funding large expenses. However, the returns are generally lower compared to other investment options.

<strong>Ideal For</strong>: Permanent life insurance is often chosen by those looking for lifelong coverage and are interested in using the policy as a savings or investment vehicle.
<h2>Choosing Between the Two:</h2>
<h3>Choose term life insurance if:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li>You need coverage for a specific period.</li>
 	<li>You have limited budget but want adequate coverage.</li>
 	<li>You prioritize simplicity and pure insurance protection.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Choose permanent life insurance if:</h3>
<ul>
 	<li>You want lifelong coverage and can afford higher premiums.</li>
 	<li>You're interested in the cash value component as a savings or investment tool.</li>
 	<li>You want to leave a legacy or provide for heirs regardless of when you pass away.</li>
</ul>
Ultimately, your choice should align with your financial goals, current circumstances, and risk tolerance. It's recommended to consult with a financial advisor or insurance professional to determine which type of policy best fits your needs and objectives.

Subscribe <a href="https://familyraksha.com/blog">Family Raksha</a> for more such articles!]]></content:encoded>

					<item>
		<title><![CDATA[Demystifying Term Life Insurance Premiums: Factors That Influence Your Rates]]></title>
		<link>https://dev.familyraksha.com/demystifying-term-life-insurance-premiums-factors/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 10 Aug 2024 09:55:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[digital]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.familyraksha.com/?p=193</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Term life insurance is a type of life insurance that provides coverage for a specific period of time, typically ranging from 5 to 30 years. During this period, if the insured person passes away, the policy pays out a death benefit to the beneficiaries named in the policy. Term life insurance premiums, the regular payments you make to maintain coverage, can vary based on several factors.

<strong>Here are the key factors that influence your term life insurance rates:</strong>
<h2>Age</h2>
Generally, younger individuals pay lower premiums because they are statistically less likely to pass away during the term of the policy. As you age, the risk of mortality increases, and so do your premiums.
<h2>Health and Medical History</h2>
Insurance companies assess your health through medical underwriting. This process involves reviewing your medical history, current health conditions, lifestyle choices (such as smoking or excessive drinking), and possibly requiring a medical examination. Better health usually leads to lower premiums.
<h2>Gender</h2>
Statistically, women tend to have longer life expectancies and lower mortality rates compared to men. As a result, women might pay slightly lower premiums for the same coverage.
<h2>Smoking and Tobacco Use</h2>
Smokers are considered higher risk due to the associated health risks. Non-smokers typically receive lower premiums than smokers.
<h2>Coverage Amount</h2>
The death benefit amount you choose directly impacts your premium. Higher coverage amounts result in higher premiums.
<h2>Term Length</h2>
The length of the term you choose also affects the premium. Longer terms usually have higher premiums since the insurance company is exposed to the risk of payout for a more extended period
<h2>Occupation and Hobbies</h2>
Riskier occupations and hobbies (like extreme sports or dangerous jobs) can increase your premiums because they increase the likelihood of accidents or injuries.
<h2>Family Medical History</h2>
A history of certain medical conditions in your family can impact your rates, as it might suggest a higher risk of those conditions affecting you.
<h2>Location</h2>
Where you live can influence your premiums. Areas with higher costs of living or higher mortality rates might result in higher premiums.
<h2>Driving Record</h2>
If you have a history of reckless driving or multiple accidents, it could be seen as an indicator of higher risk, potentially leading to higher premiums.
<h2>Foreign Travel</h2>
If you frequently travel to high-risk countries, it might lead to higher premiums due to increased exposure to health and safety risks.
<h2>Payment Frequency</h2>
Some insurers offer discounts if you pay your premiums annually instead of monthly.
<h2>Underwriting Guidelines</h2>
Each insurance company has its own underwriting guidelines and risk assessment criteria. This can lead to variations in premiums for the same individual across different insurers.
<h2>Conclusion</h2>
It's important to explore around and compare quotes from multiple insurance providers to find the best coverage and premiums for your needs. Keep in mind that while <a href="https://www.familyraksha.com/category/insurance/">term life insurance</a> premiums are generally lower than those of permanent life insurance, they increase over time as you age. Locking in a longer term while you're younger and healthier can help you secure more affordable rates.]]></content:encoded>

					<item>
		<title><![CDATA[The Top Reasons to Consider Term Life Insurance]]></title>
		<link>https://dev.familyraksha.com/the-top-reasons-to-consider-term-life-insurance/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 10 Aug 2024 09:55:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[digital]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.familyraksha.com/?p=235</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><b>Introduction</b></strong>

Life is full of uncertainties, and as responsible individuals, it's essential to plan for the unexpected. One of the most effective ways to safeguard your family's financial future is by investing in term life insurance. While there are various types of life insurance policies available, term life insurance has gained popularity for its simplicity and affordability. In this blog, we'll explore the top reasons why you should consider term life insurance as a crucial part of your financial planning.

<strong><b>Financial Protection for Your Loved Ones</b></strong>

The primary purpose of term life insurance is to provide financial security to your loved ones in the event of your untimely demise. When you purchase a term life insurance policy, you're essentially creating a safety net for your family. If you pass away during the policy term, your beneficiaries will receive a tax-free death benefit, which can help cover essential expenses such as mortgage payments, education costs, and daily living expenses. This financial cushion ensures that your loved ones can maintain their standard of living and achieve their long-term goals.

<strong><b>Affordable Premiums</b></strong>

Term life insurance is often more affordable than other types of life insurance, such as whole life or universal life insurance. This affordability makes it accessible to a wider range of individuals, including young families and those on a budget. You can choose the coverage amount and term length that best suits your needs and budget, allowing you to tailor your policy to your financial situation.

<strong><b>Flexibility in Policy Length</b></strong>

Term life insurance offers flexibility when it comes to the length of the coverage. You can select a term that aligns with your financial goals and family's needs. Common term lengths are 10, 15, 20, or 30 years. If you want coverage for a specific period, such as until your children graduate from college or until your mortgage is paid off, term life insurance allows you to do so without committing to lifelong premiums.

<strong><b>Simple and Transparent</b></strong>

Unlike some other insurance products, term life insurance is straightforward and easy to understand. You pay a fixed premium for a predetermined term, and in the event of your death during that term, your beneficiaries receive the death benefit. There are no cash values, investment components, or complicated features to navigate. This simplicity makes it easier to focus on your family's financial protection without getting bogged down in complex policy details.

<strong><b>Peace of Mind</b></strong>

Knowing that you have term life insurance in place can provide peace of mind. It's reassuring to know that, in case the unexpected happens, your family won't be left struggling financially. This peace of mind can help reduce stress and allow you to focus on enjoying life without worrying about what might happen.

<strong><b>Supplemental Coverage</b></strong>

Term life insurance can also serve as a valuable supplement to other forms of insurance, such as employer-sponsored coverage or a whole life insurance policy. It can help fill gaps in coverage or provide additional protection during specific periods when you need it most.

<strong><b>Conclusion</b></strong>

In today's uncertain world, term life insurance is a practical and cost-effective way to protect your family's financial future. It offers financial security, affordability, flexibility, and peace of mind. By considering term life insurance as part of your financial planning, you can provide your loved ones with the support they need during difficult times. Don't wait until it's too late; take the important step of securing your family's future with term life insurance today.]]></content:encoded>

Discover the unparalleled advantages of this smart and flexible coverage option, designed to provide a robust safety net for your loved ones]]></wp:meta_value>

							</item>
					<item>
		<title><![CDATA[Term Life Insurance for Different Life Stages: What You Need to Know]]></title>
		<link>https://dev.familyraksha.com/term-life-insurance-for-different-life-stages-what-you-need-to-know/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 10 Aug 2024 09:55:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[digital]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.familyraksha.com/?p=238</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><b>Introduction</b></strong>

Life is a journey filled with various stages, each presenting its own unique challenges and opportunities. Just as your needs and priorities change as you progress through different life stages, so should your financial planning, including your choice of life insurance. Term life insurance is a versatile option that can be tailored to your specific circumstances. In this blog, we'll explore how term life insurance can be a valuable asset at different life stages and what you need to know about choosing the right policy.

<strong><b>Young Adults and Term Life Insurance</b></strong>

For young adults who are just starting their careers or families, term life insurance can be a smart choice. Here's why:
<ul>
 	<li>Affordability: Term life insurance policies are typically more affordable for younger individuals. By locking in a low premium rate now, you can ensure that your loved ones have financial protection in case of your untimely passing.</li>
 	<li>Debt and Financial Responsibilities: Many young adults have student loans, credit card debt, or mortgages. A term life insurance policy can help cover these debts, ensuring that your family isn't burdened with them in the event of your death.</li>
 	<li>Income Replacement: If you're the primary breadwinner in your family, term life insurance can provide a source of income replacement for your spouse and dependents if you pass away prematurely.</li>
 	<li>Young Families and Growing Children</li>
</ul>
As your family grows and your financial responsibilities increase, term life insurance remains a crucial tool:
<ul>
 	<li>Childcare and Education: Term life insurance can help cover childcare expenses and fund your children's education if you're no longer there to provide for them.</li>
 	<li>Mortgage Protection: If you've recently purchased a home, your mortgage is likely a significant financial commitment. Term life insurance can ensure that your family can continue to make mortgage payments if you're not around.</li>
 	<li>Flexible Terms: Choose a term length that aligns with your children's expected graduation from college or the years until your mortgage is paid off.</li>
 	<li>Mid-Life and Career Advancement</li>
</ul>
As you advance in your career and accumulate assets, your life insurance needs may change:
<ul>
 	<li>Asset Protection: Term life insurance can help protect the assets you've built over the years. It can provide a safety net to cover estate taxes or other financial obligations.</li>
 	<li>Supplemental Coverage: Term life insurance can complement employer-sponsored life insurance, especially if you're relying on your employer's coverage as your primary form of protection.</li>
 	<li>Transition Planning: Consider how your life insurance fits into your retirement and estate planning. Term life insurance can be a valuable tool for transitioning wealth to the next generation.</li>
 	<li>Retirement and Legacy Planning</li>
</ul>
In your retirement years, term life insurance can continue to play a role:
<ul>
 	<li>Estate Equalization: Term life insurance can help ensure that your estate is divided equally among beneficiaries, even if some assets are not easily divisible.</li>
 	<li>Legacy and Charitable Giving: If you have philanthropic goals or want to leave a legacy, a term life insurance policy can provide a substantial donation to your chosen charities or organizations.</li>
 	<li>Final Expenses: Term life insurance can help cover final expenses, including funeral costs, so that your loved ones don't have to bear this burden.</li>
</ul>
<strong><b>Conclusion</b></strong>

Term life insurance is a versatile and cost-effective option that can adapt to your changing needs and priorities at different life stages. Whether you're a young adult, a parent, a mid-career professional, or planning for retirement, term life insurance can provide the peace of mind and financial protection you and your loved ones deserve. To make the most of this valuable tool, consult with a qualified insurance professional who can help you choose the right policy to meet your specific needs and goals.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h6>Your Plan:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>Death Coverage:</strong> Death due to any cause (e.g. natural, accidental, murder, illnesses, fire, calamities, Covid-19)</li>
</ul>
<h6>What's not Covered:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>Suicidal Cover:</strong> Suicide during first year of the policy term Death due to any type of illegal activities( e.g drink & Drive, Over speeding, Encounter during criminal activity)</li>
</ul>]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_inbuilt_benefit]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_66af5b475e8c0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[rider_benefit]]></wp:meta_key>

	<li>Cover against 4 critical illness</li>
	<li>Cash for hospitalization</li>
	<li>Surgical Care</li>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h6>Your Plan:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>Death Coverage:</strong> Death due to any cause (e.g. natural, accidental, murder, illnesses, fire, calamities, Covid-19)</li>
</ul>
<h6>What's not Covered:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>Suicidal Cover:</strong> Suicide during first year of the policy term Death due to any type of illegal activities( e.g drink & Drive, Over speeding, Encounter during criminal activity)</li>
</ul>]]></wp:meta_value>

    <li><strong>Zero Cost - </strong>Term Insurance</li>
</ul>
<h6>Your Plan:</h3>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li>All Premiums paid upto 1.5 Lac a year are exempted from tax under section 80C</li>
    <li>In case of your death the life cover paid to your nominee is completely tax free under section 10(10D)</li>
    </li>
</ul>
<h6>Zero Commission :</h3>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li>We charge no commission when you buy from us</li>
</ul>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h6>Your Plan:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>Death Coverage:</strong> Death due to any cause (e.g. natural, accidental, murder, illnesses, fire, calamities, Covid-19)</li>
</ul>
<h6>What's not Covered:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>Suicidal Cover:</strong> Suicide during first year of the policy term Death due to any type of illegal activities( e.g drink & Drive, Over speeding, Encounter during criminal activity)</li>
</ul>]]></wp:meta_value>

	<li><strong>Free - </strong>Early payout on Terminal illness</li>
    <li><strong>Zero Cost - </strong>Term Insurance</li>
</ul>
<h6>Your Plan:</h3>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li>All Premiums paid upto 1.5 Lac a year are exempted from tax under section 80C</li>
    <li>In case of your death the life cover paid to your nominee is completely tax free under section 10(10D)</li>
    </li>
</ul>
<h6>Zero Commission :</h3>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li>We charge no commission when you buy from us</li>
</ul>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_insurer_redirection_link]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[know_your_plan]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h6>Plan Details:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>In-Patient Care: </strong> Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Room rent limit: </strong>All Category Rooms Allowed</li>
	<li><strong>ICU: </strong>No Limit</li>
	<li><strong>Co-pay: </strong>100% paid by the insurer</li>
	<li><strong>Advance Technology Methods: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Pre-Hospitalization Medical Expenses: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured), upto 60 days prior to hospitalization</li>
	<li><strong>Post Hospitalization Medical Expenses: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured), upto 180 days after discharge</li>
	<li><strong>Day Care Treatment: </strong>All Day Care Procedures</li>
	<li><strong>Domiciliary Hospitalization: </strong>Hospitalization at home up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>AYUSH Treatment: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Organ Donor Cover: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Ambulance charges: </strong>Up to Rs.10,000 per year</li>
	<li><strong>No Claim Bonus: </strong>Applicable when you do not make any claim in a policy year</li>
	<li><strong>Restoration of cover: </strong>Unlimited Automatic Recharge for Related & Unrelated Illnesses.</li>
</ul>
<h6>Waiting periods:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
<li>Initial Waiting Period :- 30 days; except claims arising due to an accident, provided the same are covered. This is standard in the industry across all insurance policies.</li>
<li>Specific Illness cover :- 24 months; for slow growing diseases like knee replacement, hernia, cataract etc.</li>
<li>Existing Illness cover :- 4 years</li>
</ul>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>In-Patient Care: </strong> Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Room rent limit: </strong>All Category Rooms Allowed</li>
	<li><strong>ICU: </strong>No Limit</li>
	<li><strong>Co-pay: </strong>100% paid by the insurer</li>
	<li><strong>Advance Technology Methods: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Pre-Hospitalization Medical Expenses: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured), upto 60 days prior to hospitalization</li>
	<li><strong>Post Hospitalization Medical Expenses: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured), upto 180 days after discharge</li>
	<li><strong>Day Care Treatment: </strong>All Day Care Procedures</li>
	<li><strong>Domiciliary Hospitalization: </strong>Hospitalization at home up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>AYUSH Treatment: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Organ Donor Cover: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Ambulance charges: </strong>Up to Rs.10,000 per year</li>
	<li><strong>No Claim Bonus: </strong>Applicable when you do not make any claim in a policy year</li>
	<li><strong>Restoration of cover: </strong>Unlimited Automatic Recharge for Related & Unrelated Illnesses.</li>
</ul>
<h6>Waiting periods:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
<li>Initial Waiting Period :- 30 days; except claims arising due to an accident, provided the same are covered. This is standard in the industry across all insurance policies.</li>
<li>Specific Illness cover :- 24 months; for slow growing diseases like knee replacement, hernia, cataract etc.</li>
<li>Existing Illness cover :- 4 years</li>
</ul>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_know_your_plan]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_66b49035324bb]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plan_brochure]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[639]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plan_brochure]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_66b49048324bc]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[policy_wordings]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

<li>Initial Waiting Period :- 30 days; except claims arising due to an accident, provided the same are covered. This is standard in the industry across all insurance policies.</li>
<li>Specific Illness cover :- 24 months; for slow growing diseases like knee replacement, hernia, cataract etc.</li>
<li>Existing Illness cover :- 4 years</li>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h6>Plan Details:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
	<li><strong>In-Patient Care: </strong> Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Room rent limit: </strong>All Category Rooms Allowed</li>
	<li><strong>ICU: </strong>No Limit</li>
	<li><strong>Co-pay: </strong>100% paid by the insurer</li>
	<li><strong>Advance Technology Methods: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Pre-Hospitalization Medical Expenses: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured), upto 60 days prior to hospitalization</li>
	<li><strong>Post Hospitalization Medical Expenses: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured), upto 180 days after discharge</li>
	<li><strong>Day Care Treatment: </strong>All Day Care Procedures</li>
	<li><strong>Domiciliary Hospitalization: </strong>Hospitalization at home up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>AYUSH Treatment: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Organ Donor Cover: </strong>Up to SI (Sum Insured)</li>
	<li><strong>Ambulance charges: </strong>Up to Rs.10,000 per year</li>
	<li><strong>No Claim Bonus: </strong>Applicable when you do not make any claim in a policy year</li>
	<li><strong>Restoration of cover: </strong>Unlimited Automatic Recharge for Related & Unrelated Illnesses.</li>
</ul>
<h6>Waiting periods:-</h6>
<ul class="list-check primary m-b30">
<li>Initial Waiting Period :- 30 days; except claims arising due to an accident, provided the same are covered. This is standard in the industry across all insurance policies.</li>
<li>Specific Illness cover :- 24 months; for slow growing diseases like knee replacement, hernia, cataract etc.</li>
<li>Existing Illness cover :- 4 years</li>
</ul>]]></wp:meta_value>
